articles.headline: European Union Reaches Deal With Turkey to Return New Asylum Seekers
articles.snippet: The move to send migrants who arrive in Greece back to Turkey was a significant step amid a crisis that has left tens of thousands of people in squalid conditions.
articles.abstract: The move to send migrants who arrive in Greece back to Turkey was a significant step amid a crisis that has left tens of thousands of people in squalid conditions.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union has reached an agreement with Turkey that it hopes will ease the migrant crisis that has roiled the Continent for the past year.

articles.headline: Insurance for Critical Illness May Add Security, but at a Cost
articles.snippet: The policies have become increasingly popular, but some consumer advocates and health policy analysts question whether they are worth the expense.
articles.abstract: The policies have become increasingly popular, but some consumer advocates and health policy analysts question whether they are worth the expense.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s often pitched as an insurance policy for your health insurance policy.

articles.headline: In a Rebel Camp in Colombia, Marx and Free Love Reign
articles.snippet: For the guerrillas of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, many of whom have never set foot in their country’s cities, the prospect of peace after 50 years means an uncertain future.
articles.abstract: For the guerrillas of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, many of whom have never set foot in their country’s cities, the prospect of peace after 50 years means an uncertain future.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN THE MOUNTAINS OF COLOMBIA — The rebel camp is a Communist time capsule. An old guerrilla fighter sings songs about Che Guevara on his guitar as a crowd leans in to listen, armed with rifles and grenades.

articles.headline: Presidential Candidates Woo Arizona Voters on Immigration
articles.snippet: Arizona is both a magnet for retirees and home to a growing Latino population. The state’s electorate is deeply divided on the question of immigration.
articles.abstract: Arizona is both a magnet for retirees and home to a growing Latino population. The state’s electorate is deeply divided on the question of immigration.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — When Donald J. Trump campaigns in Arizona, he talks up the endorsements he has received from Jan Brewer, the former governor who signed some of the nation’s toughest immigration laws, and Sheriff Joe Arpaio, whose aggressive pursuit of illegal immigrants has prompted discrimination charges by the Justice Department.

articles.headline: Hulk Hogan Awarded $115 Million in Privacy Suit Against Gawker
articles.snippet: A Florida jury delivered a verdict in favor of the former wrestler in a suit over publication of a sex tape. It also found the site’s founder and its former editor liable.
articles.abstract: A Florida jury delivered a verdict in favor of the former wrestler in a suit over publication of a sex tape. It also found the site’s founder and its former editor liable.
articles.lead_paragraph: The retired wrestler Hulk Hogan was awarded $115 million in damages on Friday by a Florida jury in an invasion of privacy case against Gawker.com over its publication of a sex tape — an astounding figure that tops the $100 million he had asked for, that will probably grow before the trial concludes, and that could send a cautionary signal to online publishers despite the likelihood of an appeal by Gawker.
articles.byline: By Nick Madigan and Ravi Somaiya

articles.headline: Accusations of Sexism and Racism Shake Ad Agency and Industry
articles.snippet: After J. Walter Thompson’s chief steps down, questions are raised about Madison Avenue’s culture and diversity in an era posing new challenges.
articles.abstract: After J. Walter Thompson’s chief steps down, questions are raised about Madison Avenue’s culture and diversity in an era posing new challenges.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Thursday afternoon at J. Walter Thompson’s headquarters on Lexington Avenue in New York, the departing chief executive, Gustavo Martinez, handed the reins of the storied advertising agency to his successor, Tamara Ingram.

articles.headline: Carrier Workers See Costs, Not Benefits, of Global Trade
articles.snippet: As factory jobs move abroad, the divide between the political and economic elite and the rest of Americans widens, placing the two groups at odds.
articles.abstract: As factory jobs move abroad, the divide between the political and economic elite and the rest of Americans widens, placing the two groups at odds.
articles.lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — The fuzzy video, shot by a worker on the floor of a Carrier factory here in the American heartland last month, captured the raging national debate over trade and the future of the working class in 3 minutes 32 seconds.

articles.headline: Republican Leaders Map a Strategy to Derail Donald Trump
articles.snippet: If aggressive efforts to deny Mr. Trump the presidential nomination fail, the party leaders say they will try to field an independent candidate for the general election.
articles.abstract: If aggressive efforts to deny Mr. Trump the presidential nomination fail, the party leaders say they will try to field an independent candidate for the general election.
articles.lead_paragraph: Republican leaders adamantly opposed to Donald J. Trump’s candidacy are preparing a 100-day campaign to deny him the presidential nomination, starting with an aggressive battle in Wisconsin’s April 5 primary and extending into the summer, with a delegate-by-delegate lobbying effort that would cast Mr. Trump as a calamitous choice for the general election.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: In Louisiana, the Poor Lack Legal Defense
articles.snippet: The constitutional obligation to provide criminal defense for the poor has been endangered by funding problems across the country, but nowhere more so than in Louisiana.
articles.abstract: The constitutional obligation to provide criminal defense for the poor has been endangered by funding problems across the country, but nowhere more so than in Louisiana.
articles.lead_paragraph: ABBEVILLE, La. — It was arraignment morning at the Vermilion Parish courthouse, the monthly catalog of bad decisions, hot tempers, hard hearts and hard luck. Natasha George, who until recently was one of 10 lawyers defending the poor of the parish, stood before the full gallery of defendants.

articles.headline: A View of ISIS’s Evolution in New Details of Paris Attacks
articles.snippet: A 55-page French report details how the attackers used disciplined communications, identified soft targets and perfected bomb-making techniques after two years of failures.
articles.abstract: A 55-page French report details how the attackers used disciplined communications, identified soft targets and perfected bomb-making techniques after two years of failures.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investigators found crates’ worth of disposable cellphones. All around Paris, they found traces of improved bomb-making materials. And they began piecing together a multilayered terrorist attack that evaded detection until much too late.
articles.byline: By Rukmini Callimachi, Alissa J. Rubin and Laure Fourquet

articles.headline: Apple vs. the F.B.I.: How the Case Could Play Out
articles.snippet: The New York Times reporters Katie Benner, who covers technology, and Matt Apuzzo, who covers national security, debate the iPhone case as it heads to a hearing.
articles.abstract: The New York Times reporters Katie Benner, who covers technology, and Matt Apuzzo, who covers national security, debate the iPhone case as it heads to a hearing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple is getting ready for a busy week.
articles.byline: By Katie Benner and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: Donald Trump Courts Wary Jewish Voters
articles.snippet: Donald J. Trump, whose disregard for the sensitivities of various religious and ethnic groups has hit a nerve among Jewish organizations, faces a difficult sell Monday.
articles.abstract: Donald J. Trump, whose disregard for the sensitivities of various religious and ethnic groups has hit a nerve among Jewish organizations, faces a difficult sell Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: On paper, Donald J. Trump is the last candidate one would expect to raise eyebrows within the Jewish community.

articles.headline: As Obama Arrives, Cuba Tightens Grip on Dissent
articles.snippet: Cuba, a police state working out how much to open up to the world and to its own people, has gone above and beyond to prevent embarrassing surprises.
articles.abstract: Cuba, a police state working out how much to open up to the world and to its own people, has gone above and beyond to prevent embarrassing surprises.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAVANA — President Obama touched down in Cuba on Sunday, pledging to interact directly with the Cuban people and accelerate engagement between the United States and Cuba after more than a half-century of hostility.
articles.byline: By Damien Cave and Julie Hirschfeld Davis

articles.headline: Amazon Leans on Government in Its Quest to Be a Delivery Powerhouse
articles.snippet: New uses for commercial drones, 33-foot trucks, improved roads and bridges: Amazon and its lobbyists urge officials to support expansion efforts.
articles.abstract: New uses for commercial drones, 33-foot trucks, improved roads and bridges: Amazon and its lobbyists urge officials to support expansion efforts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ever since Jeff Bezos started the website Amazon to sell books, he has wrestled with how to deliver its products as quickly and cheaply as possible. Today, Amazon, now a retail giant, remains obsessed with this issue, building its own fleet of drones, buying trailers for trucks and signing up drivers for on-demand deliveries.

articles.headline: U.S. Casts Wary Eye on Australian Port Leased by Chinese
articles.snippet: Critics contend that the Chinese bought a front-row seat to spy on naval operations at the port of Darwin, which serves as a host base for the United States Marines.
articles.abstract: Critics contend that the Chinese bought a front-row seat to spy on naval operations at the port of Darwin, which serves as a host base for the United States Marines.
articles.lead_paragraph: DARWIN, Australia — The port in this remote northern Australian outpost is little more than a graying old wharf jutting into crocodile-infested waters. On a recent day, there was stifling heat but not a ship in sight. “Our pissy little port,” as John Robinson, a flamboyant local tycoon, calls it.

articles.headline: Hollywood Divided Over Movie Streaming Service
articles.snippet: The Screening Room, a start-up supported by AMC, wants consumers to pay $50 to rent big-budget movies on the same day they arrive in theaters.
articles.abstract: The Screening Room, a start-up supported by AMC, wants consumers to pay $50 to rent big-budget movies on the same day they arrive in theaters.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Tech entrepreneurs are always rolling into Hollywood with new services that are supposed to modernize the movie business. If only the dusty, old, dimwitted studios and theater companies would stop dragging their feet and sign up, all of the entertainment industry’s problems would be solved.

articles.headline: As Coal’s Future Grows Murkier, Banks Pull Financing
articles.snippet: After helping to drive Wall Street’s profits for generations, the coal industry is in a free fall, and even daring investors are reluctant to risk trying to save it.
articles.abstract: After helping to drive Wall Street’s profits for generations, the coal industry is in a free fall, and even daring investors are reluctant to risk trying to save it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of miners were on strike and coal prices were skyrocketing in October 1902. Afraid of unrest, President Theodore Roosevelt sought the help of John Pierpont Morgan.

articles.headline: Older Voters May Be Hillary Clinton’s Answer to Bernie Sanders’s Youth Appeal
articles.snippet: Mr. Sanders’s message has made him the choice of the Snapchat generation, but Mrs. Clinton is doing fine counting on voters who came of age with Polaroids.
articles.abstract: Mr. Sanders’s message has made him the choice of the Snapchat generation, but Mrs. Clinton is doing fine counting on voters who came of age with Polaroids.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAKE WORTH, Fla. — The afternoon of the Florida primaries last week, Sylvia Wolfson, 87, and more than a dozen other retirees scurried around an office set up with trays of cookies from Costco and large-print instructions on how to unlock the restroom door.

articles.headline: The Mutual Dependence of Donald Trump and the News Media
articles.snippet: While Mr. Trump’s presidential bid benefits from constant coverage, that coverage is also a lifeline to news outlets as they jockey for survival.
articles.abstract: While Mr. Trump’s presidential bid benefits from constant coverage, that coverage is also a lifeline to news outlets as they jockey for survival.
articles.lead_paragraph: Did you catch the Trump-Kelly bout Friday night? What a show.

articles.headline: Self-Correcting Beyond a Web Era Marked by Sensationalism
articles.snippet: By the time a jury awarded Hulk Hogan damages from Gawker for its publication of a sex tape, the site and others were already self-correcting in the direction of privacy.
articles.abstract: By the time a jury awarded Hulk Hogan damages from Gawker for its publication of a sex tape, the site and others were already self-correcting in the direction of privacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: The trial involving Gawker and Terry Bollea, better known as Hulk Hogan, over the publication of a sex video raised timeless legal questions about privacy and freedom of the press. The result, with the jury awarding Mr. Bollea $115 million in compensatory damages, could threaten Gawker’s existence.

articles.headline: First Step in Conservatives’ Supreme Court Fight: Agreeing on a Message
articles.snippet: The factions opposing Merrick B. Garland’s nomination to the Supreme Court are split over whether to attack him directly or steer the debate away from his merits.
articles.abstract: The factions opposing Merrick B. Garland’s nomination to the Supreme Court are split over whether to attack him directly or steer the debate away from his merits.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The live shot on MSNBC was less than an hour away, so Curt A. Levey, executive director of the FreedomWorks Foundation, a conservative group determined to block President Obama’s Supreme Court nominee, sat with his communications director for a quick review of what his message to the American public should be.

articles.headline: John Roberts Criticized Supreme Court Confirmation Process, Before There Was a Vacancy
articles.snippet: Ten days before Justice Antonin Scalia died, Chief Justice Roberts said that the Senate should ensure that nominees are qualified, and leave politics out of it.
articles.abstract: Ten days before Justice Antonin Scalia died, Chief Justice Roberts said that the Senate should ensure that nominees are qualified, and leave politics out of it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Last month, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. delivered some blunt remarks about the Supreme Court confirmation process. The Senate should ensure that nominees are qualified, he said, and leave politics out of it.

articles.headline: Cuba Meeting Between Obama and Castro Exposes Old Grievances
articles.snippet: During an extraordinary news conference, the leaders’ exchanges underscored how far the two nations have to travel to fully restore relations.
articles.abstract: During an extraordinary news conference, the leaders’ exchanges underscored how far the two nations have to travel to fully restore relations.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAVANA — President Obama stood beside President Raúl Castro on Monday and declared a “new day” of openness between the United States and Cuba, but old grievances and disputes over human rights marred a groundbreaking meeting and underscored lingering impediments to a historic thaw.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Damien Cave

articles.headline: A Shake-Up at Valeant Signals the End of an Era
articles.snippet: Valeant’s chief will step down, one of many changes made by the drug maker, which faces a growing list of questions from investors and regulators.
articles.abstract: Valeant’s chief will step down, one of many changes made by the drug maker, which faces a growing list of questions from investors and regulators.
articles.lead_paragraph: As recently as last summer, J. Michael Pearson styled himself as a brash and bold executive with a new way of thriving in pharmaceuticals: buying other companies, slashing costs and sharply raising prices on undervalued drugs.
articles.byline: By Katie Thomas and Andrew Pollack
